hints.content: Start by understanding the process of revealing cards. You take the top card, reveal it, and then move the next card to the bottom. This pattern continues until all cards are revealed.
Think about how you can manipulate the order of the cards in the deck. Since the cards have unique integers, sorting the deck initially might help you achieve the desired revealing order.
Consider using a queue to simulate the deck. This will allow you to easily add cards to the bottom and remove cards from the top, mimicking the revealing process.
When you sort the deck, remember that the smallest card should be revealed first. This means you might need to rearrange the cards in a specific order before starting the revealing process.
Try to visualize the process with a small example. For instance, if your sorted deck is [2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17], how would you rearrange it to ensure that the cards reveal in increasing order?
As you simulate the revealing process, keep track of the order in which cards are revealed. This will help you verify if your rearrangement is correct.
Consider using a list to store the final order of revealed cards. After each reveal, append the revealed card to this list and adjust the deck accordingly.
Make sure to handle edge cases, such as when the deck has only one card. This will help ensure your solution is robust and works for all possible inputs.
You might want to use a loop that continues until all cards are revealed. Within this loop, implement the logic to reveal the top card and move the next card to the bottom of the deck.

Finally, think about how to return the final order of the cards. Once all cards are revealed, you should return the list that contains the order in which they were revealed, ensuring it's in the format specified in the problem.

questionNotes: Each value in deck is unique and falls within the range 1 <= deck[i] <= 10^6.
The return format should be a list representing the order of revealed cards, starting with the top of the deck.
